Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Visualization of ZnO Nanoparticle Sunblock Efficacy on Ex Vivo and in Vivo Nude Mouse Tissue

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modified Title: In Vivo Imaging of Hepatocyte Zonation in Mouse Liver

I worked with Professor Chen-Yuan Dong at National Taiwan University last summer as an EAPSI Fellow. As the project title suggests, we were originally going to investigate the efficacy of zinc oxide nanoparticle-based sunblocks against UV radiation. However, we later decided that my project should focus on investigating properties of the liver. This was mainly because other members of the Dong group were working on the liver at the time of my arrival, and a collaboration with the Dong group’s current work would allow for a higher chance of producing results within the seven-week project timeframe.

Our project involved in vivo imaging of the liver using multiphoton microscopy (MPM). MPM is a special microscopy method that allows us to look inside the liver without actually cutting the liver open. We used this technique to observe the liver inside a living mouse (the mouse was under anesthesia during the entire procedure). A primary liver function is to metabolize molecules, and different zones of the liver are responsible for metabolizing different types of molecules. Our experiment was designed to identify these different zones in vivo. We injected a special molecule (CFDA) that only fluoresces after it is metabolized and subsequently imaged the liver. We were able to observe a preferential metabolism of this molecule during our imaging, which implied the existence of this zonation (see figure).

This research is important for better understanding how the liver works. Many diseases such as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease are becoming more common, and it is important to understand how these diseases develop in order to counteract them. Looking at tissue "in vivo" is very advantageous because it allows scientists to see dynamics that are much harder to see when looking at dead tissue.

Professor Dong is an expert at MPM imaging in biological tissue and uses it to look at many organs including the liver, the skin, and the intestines.

My research at Cornell University is with Professor Chris Xu. Professor Xu is an expert at using MPM to look deep within biological tissue. Deep-tissue imaging allows scientists to visualize a larger section of tissue, which allows more research on diseases and disease prevention. At Cornell we are using MPM to look at mouse brains "in vivo" (the mice are also under anesthesia during the entire procedure). We are trying to look as deep into the brain as possible, and we recently imaged 1.6mm below the surface, which is approximately twice the maximum imaging depth in 2009.
